entry.title: Bring back Manifest V2 extensions to Chrome!
entry.summary: These flags have been marked for deprecation since Chrome 137 and could be removed at any time. This guide may not work at some point in the near future. In Chrome 139 and above, Manifest V2 extensions are "no longer" supported. This is not the case, as…
entry.content:
These flags have been marked for deprecation since Chrome 137 and could be removed at any time. This guide may not work at some point in the near future.

In Chrome 139 and above, Manifest V2 extensions are "no longer" supported. This is not the case, as the browser still internally supports these extensions. Through some digging in the Chromium source, we (LagLife and myself) discovered that there is actually a command-line flag to re-enable these extensions. 

To re-enable Manifest V2 extensions:

Self-promo: Linux users are able to skip this guide and use LinuxPatcher to automatically modify Chrome's shortcuts to launch with the required flag.

When launching Chrome, you will have to append a command-line flag to Chrome's executable. There are two flags that work, which are for different scenarios.

Option #1
--disable-features="ExtensionManifestV2Disabled, ExtensionManifestV2Unsupported, ExtensionManifestV2DeprecationWarning"

This flag re-enables Manifest V2 extensions, hides the deprecation warning in chrome://extensions and also allows users to install Manifest V2 extensions from the Chrome Web Store. 

Option #2
--enable-features="AllowLegacyMV2Extensions"

This flag re-enables Manifest V2 extensions that were previously installed. This does not allow installing extensions from the Chrome Web Store.

How was this discovered?

This was discovered in the run_py_tests.py file in the Chromium source, which has a test that disables Google's absurd decision as many tests still rely on Manifest V2.

The extension_features.cc file has various "features" relating to disabling Manifest V2, which is where ExtensionManifestV2DeprecationWarning were discovered.

entry.title: Microsoft Edge Source Code
entry.summary: Please note that this source only contains headers and cannot be used to compile a working version of Edge. You thought Microsoft Edge was proprietary, didn't you. Well, because of Panasonic (of all things), we have some of the source code for Microsoft Edge. You…
entry.content:
Please note that this source only contains headers and cannot be used to compile a working version of Edge.

You thought Microsoft Edge was proprietary, didn't you. Well, because of Panasonic (of all things), we have some of the source code for Microsoft Edge.

You read that title right! Panasonic (of all things) shared part of the Microsoft Edge source code on their website. The page with the downloads is here and the downloads are below:

Version Download
80.0.361.61 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/80.0.361.61_sc.zip
84.0.522.75 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/84.0.522.75_sc.zip
89.0.774.68 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/89.0.774.68_sc.zip
90.0.818.66 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/90.0.818.66_sc.zip
92.0.902.67 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/92.0.902.67_sc.zip
100.0.1185.36 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/100.0.1185.36_sc.zip
106.0.1370.47 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/106.0.1370.47_sc.zip
122.0.2365.106 https://contents.oss-src-distribution.panasonic.com/oss/pc/122.0.2365.106_sc.zip

Hilltraud (on the OpenXP Discord server) also discovered that Microsoft provides partial source for Edge on their Third Party Source site.
